greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Positions of records in A064097.
comment: With a(1) = 1, a(n) is the smallest number m such that the number of iterations of r -> r - (largest divisor d < r) needed to reach 1 starting at r = m is equal to n-1. (See Example section.) - _Jaroslav Krizek_, Feb 15 2010
link: Robert G. Wilson v, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..56
example: a(6)=11 because m=11 requires 6-1 = 5 iterations of r -> r - (largest divisor d < r) to reach 1 (the 5 iterations are 11-1=10, 10-5=5, 5-1=4, 4-2=2, and 2-1=1) and 11 is the smallest such number m. - _Jaroslav Krizek_, Feb 15 2010
results.author: _Hugo Pfoertner_, Feb 17 2006
ext: a(1)=1 inserted by _Robert G. Wilson v_, Mar 16 2020
